title: How to Win a Running Race

steps.title: Warm up before the race.
steps.content: Warm up before the race. Practice steadily every day with good workout routines that make your muscles hurt. The day before the race, work out a little and then rest up well. [1] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Choose your best starting position.
steps.content: Choose your best starting position. Once the ref says "set" breathe in air. It helps you last longer in a sprint as you should breathe in your nose and out your mouth, it keeps you from cramping up in a longer race.

steps.title: Keep a steady start.
steps.content: Keep a steady start. If you get a shaky one you won't get a good position.

steps.title: Swing your arms.
steps.content: Swing your arms. The faster the better, your legs will go faster as well. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Don't sprint at the beginning of a distance race.
steps.content: Don't sprint at the beginning of a distance race. This is a waste of energy and it tires you out. Just sprint a bit for a couple of seconds to help you keep in a good position, then just jog to not get tired and on the last laps, sprint hard to come in a high position. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Stay humble.
steps.content: Stay humble. If you are very proud of yourself then you think it is too easy and you will come in a fairly low position. But keep your self confidence saying " I can do it". But don't have "false humility" and think you are a terrible runner; that will make you do worse.

steps.title: Don't get distracted.
steps.content: Don't get distracted. This will throw your rhythm off. Don't be startled by the pistol if one is used.

steps.title: If you are running in an oval racetrack, try to be in the lane closest to the center because it takes you the shortest time to complete the track.
steps.content: If you are running in an oval racetrack, try to be in the lane closest to the center because it takes you the shortest time to complete the track.

steps.title: If you'd like, drink an energy drink or eat chocolate before the race.
steps.content: If you'd like, drink an energy drink or eat chocolate before the race. It will give you extra strength, but do not do it in a marathon! [4] X Research source

steps.title: Keep your hands loose in a long distance run.
steps.content: Keep your hands loose in a long distance run. Clenching them will tighten your muscles and make it harder to run. If you get tired during a long distance race, just speed walk using your arms.
